question: To be a good driver, you need to be:

options.text: Mindful, responsible, familiar with your vehicle, and patient
Always in a hurry to reach your destination
Focused only on your own needs

explanation: Good drivers are mindful of themselves and others, responsible for following rules, familiar with their vehicle, and patient and level-headed.

question: Before starting the engine, you should take a moment to check in with yourself to ensure you're healthy enough to drive safely.
explanation: Yes, before starting the engine, take a moment to check if you're healthy in a way that supports wise decision-making, self-control, and situational awareness.

question: Seeing well is important to safe driving.
explanation: Good vision is so important that the law requires you to pass a vision test before getting your driver license. It helps you identify traffic hazards and respond to problems.

question: If you are required to wear corrective lenses while driving, you should:

options.text: Only wear them during the day
Always wear them when driving and avoid dark or tinted lenses at night
Wear dark tinted lenses for better night vision

explanation: If required to wear corrective lenses, always wear them when driving and avoid using dark or tinted corrective lenses at night.

question: Peripheral vision helps you:

options.text: Spot vehicles and potential trouble out of the corner of your eye while looking ahead

explanation: Peripheral vision allows you to spot vehicles and other potential trouble out of the corner of your eye while you're still looking ahead.

question: When driving at night and bothered by glare from oncoming headlights, you should:

options.text: Look directly at the oncoming lights
Watch the right edge of the road and use it as a steering guide
Speed up to pass the oncoming vehicle quickly

explanation: To avoid glare from oncoming lights, watch the right edge of the road and use it as a steering guide while ensuring your headlights are on.

question: When driving at night, you should be able to stop inside the lit area created by your headlights.
explanation: You should reduce your speed and increase following distances at night so you can stop inside the lit area created by your headlights.

question: It is illegal to drive while wearing earbuds, earphones, headphones, or headsets that broadcast sound or cancel noise.
explanation: It is against the law to drive a vehicle while wearing earbuds, earphones, headphones, or headsets that broadcast sound or cancel noise. Sound cues are important for safe driving.

question: You can use a hands-free device while driving if:

options.text: It is used in both ears
It is used in one ear and complies with WAC 204-10-045

explanation: You can use a hands-free device in one ear if it complies with Washington Administrative Code statute 204-10-045. However, permit and intermediate license holders cannot use any mobile device.

question: If you have an instruction permit or intermediate license, you cannot use a cell phone or any mobile electronic device while driving, even if it is hands-free.
explanation: Instruction permit and intermediate license holders cannot use a cell phone or any mobile electronic device while driving, even if it is hands-free.

question: Impaired driving happens when:

options.text: Anything makes it hard to think straight, respond quickly, or control your car

explanation: Impaired driving happens when anything makes it hard for you to think straight, respond quickly, or control your car, including alcohol, drugs, or being tired.

question: Alcohol can affect drivers by causing:

options.text: Improved reaction time and better vision
Relaxation, drowsiness, blurry vision, reduced reaction times, and overconfidence

explanation: Alcohol causes feelings of relaxation and drowsiness, blurry vision, reduced reaction times and concentration, difficulty understanding situations, and overconfidence leading to risky behavior.

question: There is no safe amount of cannabis for driving.
explanation: There is no safe amount of cannabis for driving. Driving after consuming any cannabis is illegal for all ages, even though recreational use is legal for those 21 and over.

question: Cannabis can impair drivers by causing:

options.text: Reduced attention, slower reactions, decreased car handling, inability to judge distances, and drowsiness

explanation: Cannabis impairs attention, reaction time, coordination, car handling, distance judgment, and causes drowsiness and loss of motor coordination.

question: Just because a drug is legal does not mean it is safe to use while driving.
explanation: Many legally obtained over-the-counter and prescription drugs can impact driving ability. Impaired driving is a criminal behavior regardless of whether the drug is legal.

question: Over-the-counter drugs taken for headaches, colds, or allergies can:

options.text: Make a person drowsy and affect driving

explanation: Over-the-counter drugs for headaches, colds, or allergies can make a person drowsy, which could affect your driving, reflexes, judgment, vision, and alertness.

question: When starting a new prescription medication or taking a higher dose, you should:

options.text: Drive immediately to test its effects
Wait until you know what effect it has on your judgment, coordination, and reaction time

explanation: Do not drive if you just started taking prescription drugs for the first time, started a new medication, or started a higher dose until you know its effects on your judgment, coordination, and reaction time.

question: Warnings against 'operating heavy machinery' on medication labels include driving a vehicle.
explanation: Warnings against 'operating heavy machinery' on medication labels include driving a vehicle. Always read warning labels before driving.

question: Taking medications with alcohol can:

options.text: Cancel out the effects of both
Cause severe impairment and multiply the effects of alcohol

explanation: Many drugs multiply the effects of alcohol or have other side effects. A medication that doesn't impact you alone could cause severe impairment when combined with alcohol.

question: Polydrug use is:

options.text: The mixing or taking of more than one type of drug

explanation: Polydrug use is the mixing or taking of more than one type of drug, including alcohol, cannabis, illegal drugs, prescription drugs, over-the-counter medicines, and other substances.

question: Polydrug use is the most common impairment involved in fatal crashes.
explanation: Polydrug use is the most common impairment involved in fatal crashes. Mixing substances can produce effects greater than any drug on its own.

question: Fatigue is caused by:

options.text: Physical or mental strain, repetitive tasks, illness, or lack of sleep

explanation: Fatigue is caused by physical or mental strain, repetitive tasks, illness, or lack of sleep. Like alcohol and drugs, fatigue impairs your vision and judgment.

question: Signs of driver fatigue include:

options.text: Difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, lane drifting, and missing exits

explanation: Warning signs include difficulty focusing, forgetting the last few miles, frequent blinking or heavy eyelids, drifting from lane, swerving, tailgating, hitting rumble strips, trouble keeping head up, missing exits or signs, and feeling restless, irritable, or aggressive.

question: Most people need how many hours of sleep to stay alert while driving?
explanation: Most people need 7 to 9 hours of sleep to stay alert. Getting adequate sleep before a trip is essential to prevent drowsy driving.

question: During long trips, you should plan to stop about every:
explanation: Plan to stop about every 100 miles or 2 hours during long trips to prevent fatigue and maintain alertness.

question: If you're traveling alone and start to feel tired, you should:

options.text: Turn up the radio and keep driving
Pull off the road and take a 20-minute nap
Drink an energy drink and continue
Open all windows and drive faster

explanation: If you start to feel tired, pull off the road and take a 20-minute nap. It's better to stop and sleep than to risk causing an accident.

question: If you're feeling anxious while driving, you might:

options.text: Be preoccupied and drive too fast

explanation: Emotions affect your driving. If you're anxious, you might be preoccupied and allow your foot to be too heavy on the accelerator. Understanding how feelings affect behavior helps you make better decisions.

question: Which technique can help calm down before driving?

options.text: Breathe in through your nose and exhale like cooling hot soup
Check social media one more time

explanation: Breathing techniques help calm you down: breathe in through your nose and exhale like you're cooling hot soup. You can also count slowly from 1 to 20 or backwards from 100 by 3.

question: Aggressive driving is:

options.text: A traffic offense when a driver endangers people or property

explanation: Aggressive driving is a traffic offense that occurs when a driver purposely does something that endangers people or property, such as actions that require others to protect themselves.

question: Which of the following is considered aggressive driving?

options.text: Speeding, following too close, making unsafe lane changes, and failing to obey traffic control devices

explanation: Aggressive driving includes speeding, following too close, making unsafe lane changes, using improper signaling, failing to obey traffic control devices, and driving too close to pedestrians or cyclists.

question: Street racing and unauthorized street demonstrations can result in fines, jail time, and vehicle impoundment.
explanation: Because street racing and unauthorized street demonstrations are so dangerous, penalties are severe and can include fines, jail time, and vehicle impoundment for participants and those who assist.

question: Road rage is:

options.text: A criminal offense involving violent behavior with a vehicle or weapon

explanation: Road rage is a criminal offense - an angry response to something on the road that leads to violent behavior with a vehicle or other weapon toward another driver, passenger, or road user.

question: Things that can contribute to road rage include:

options.text: Having plenty of time for your trip
Stress, tight schedules, traffic, or non-driving frustrations

explanation: Many things can contribute to road rage including stress, tight schedules, traffic, or non-driving frustrations. Give yourself plenty of time to travel and show grace to others.

question: Signs that you might be experiencing road rage include:

options.text: Following too close, speeding, weaving in traffic, using horn excessively, and flashing headlights

explanation: Road rage signs include having violent thoughts, verbally disapproving of others, not obeying traffic laws, following too close, speeding, weaving in traffic, beating traffic lights, using horn or flashing headlights excessively, brake checking, or passing to teach a lesson.

question: If you are the victim of road rage, you should:

options.text: Distance yourself, take a deep breath, move out of the way, and call police if necessary
Make hand gestures at the other driver

explanation: When facing road rage, distance yourself physically and mentally, take a deep breath and move out of the way, avoid aggressive responses, keep eyes on the road, drive to populated areas if followed, and call police if necessary.

question: When reporting road rage to 911, you should provide:

options.text: Only the color of the vehicle
Location, plate number, direction of travel, vehicle colors, weapons involved, summary of incident, and your role

explanation: When reporting road rage, provide: location vehicles were last seen, plate number (if known), direction of travel, road/highway, vehicle colors, weapons involved (if applicable), summary of what happened, and your role (victim or witness).

question: Teen drivers are more prone to taking risks because the part of their brain responsible for judgment and decision making is still developing.
explanation: The part of the brain responsible for judgment and decision making is still developing in teens, which means they can be more prone to taking risks or miscalculating situations.

question: Making informed decisions while driving can:

options.text: Increase awareness, promote responsible driving, and reduce crashes

explanation: Informed decisions increase awareness through constant analysis, promote responsible driving by understanding consequences, and reduce crashes by anticipating potential problems.

question: To make good decisions while driving, you should:

options.text: Only watch the car directly in front of you
Inform yourself with mirror checks, prepare the vehicle, and do final checks before maneuvering
Focus only on your own needs

explanation: Good decisions require: informing yourself with mirror checks about the whole situation, preparing the vehicle to arrive at hazards in the right position and speed, and doing a final check before maneuvering.

question: Older drivers can be more susceptible to serious injuries in vehicle crashes, but many remain safe and competent drivers well into their later years.
explanation: While older drivers may be more susceptible to injuries and experience changes in physical and mental capabilities, many remain safe and competent drivers well into their later years.

question: The OODA Loop stands for:
explanation: OODA Loop is a problem-solving tool: Observe the situation, Orient using knowledge and experience, Decide on the safest action, and Act smoothly and decisively.

question: Problem solving on the road may require you to make thoughtful changes like:

options.text: Modifying speed, adjusting lane position, or changing direction

explanation: Problem solving on the road requires modifying your speed, adjusting your lane position to reduce risk and avoid hazards, or changing your direction/path to get to a safe place to reassess.

question: You should try not to surprise other people on the road and communicate your intentions to avoid creating problems.
explanation: You should not surprise other road users. Communicate your intentions to other drivers to avoid creating problems.

question: Distracted driving is:

options.text: Any activity that takes your attention away from the primary task of driving

explanation: Distracted driving is any activity that takes a person's attention away from the primary task of driving. All distractions endanger driver, passengers, and others on the road.

question: Distractions while driving come in four types:

options.text: Inside the vehicle, outside the vehicle, physical, and mental

explanation: Distractions come in four types: inside the vehicle (phones, eating, radio, passengers), outside (billboards, crashes), physical (fatigue, discomfort), and mental (daydreaming, worrying, emotions).

question: Distracted drivers are more prone to:

options.text: Swerving out of lane, speeding or driving too slowly, and failing to see traffic signals

explanation: Distracted drivers are more prone to swerving out of lane, speeding or driving too slowly, failing to see traffic signals, stop signs, motorcyclists, bicyclists, or pedestrians, following too closely, and other dangerous behaviors.

question: Strategies to avoid distractions include:

options.text: Plan ahead, put your phone away, and be observant
Checking your phone at red lights

explanation: Key strategies to avoid distractions are: plan ahead, put your phone away, and be observant. Eliminate distractions inside your vehicle and stay focused on driving.

question: By keeping your full attention on the road, you can:

options.text: React faster, make better decisions, improve situational awareness, and reduce stress

explanation: Keeping full attention on the road allows you to react faster, make better decisions, improve situational awareness, and reduce stress and fatigue.

question: In Washington State, you cannot hold any electronic device while driving, regardless of age or experience.
explanation: Washington State has strict laws - you cannot hold any electronic device while driving (like cell phones, tablets, or gaming devices), regardless of age or experience.

question: Even though hands-free devices are permitted, the notifications, bright lights, and visual cues of your phone can still be dangerous distractions.
explanation: While hands-free devices are permitted, anything that takes your eyes and mind off the road can still be dangerous. Phone notifications, bright lights, and visual cues are all significant distractions.

question: Fines for violating the distracted driving law:

options.text: Can be doubled after your first violation

explanation: A law enforcement officer can issue a ticket for violating the distracted driving law with heavy fines. Fines after your first violation can be doubled.

question: Smart drivers are:

options.text: Aware, able to control their vehicle, predictable, thoughtful, and intentional

explanation: Smart drivers are aware of what's happening, able to control their vehicle, predictable to others with signaling and smooth movements, thoughtful with decisions, and intentional when learning and using driving skills.

question: The four types of attention important for driving are:
explanation: The four types are: switching attention (quickly changing focus), divided attention (performing several things simultaneously), focused attention (concentrating on one task), and sustained attention (maintaining focus over time).

question: To help pay attention while driving, you should:

options.text: Eliminate distractions, be well-rested, silence electronics, limit passengers and pets, and resist multitasking
Bring snacks and eat while driving

explanation: Things that help attention: eliminate distractions inside your vehicle, be well-rested, put away and silence electronics, limit number of passengers and pets, and resist multitasking behind the wheel.

question: Visual searching and scanning involve:

options.text: Using your eyes to check surroundings and moving your head, neck, and body to see as much as possible

explanation: Visual searching means using your eyes to actively check surroundings. Scanning involves also moving your head, neck, and body so you can see as much as possible around your vehicle.

question: Make sure you are traveling at a speed that supports your ability to search and scan effectively.
explanation: Constant visual searching supports your ability to drive safely. Make sure you are traveling at a speed that supports your ability to search and scan effectively.

question: When scanning to the front, look ahead for:

options.text: Only the vehicle directly in front of you
Traffic situations to steer around, blockages hiding hazards, feet/wheels/shadows around parked vehicles, and what's happening beyond the vehicle ahead

explanation: Scanning to the front means looking for traffic situations to steer around, blockages that might hide pedestrians/cyclists/vehicles, feet/wheels/shadows around parked vehicles, and what's happening beyond the vehicle in front of you.

question: When scanning to the side at intersections, you should:

options.text: Pay close attention to vehicles, pedestrians, and cyclists approaching from left and right, and watch for movement when view is obscured

explanation: At intersections, pay close attention to vehicles, pedestrians, and cyclists from left and right. Watch for pedestrians and cyclists crossing. When foliage or objects obscure your view, watch for movement.

question: Before turning, you should:

options.text: Check side mirrors and do an over-shoulder check for bicyclists or pedestrians

explanation: Before turning, check your side mirrors and do an over-shoulder check for bicyclists or pedestrians who might be alongside you or about to cross the street.

question: It is essential to check traffic behind you when you:

options.text: Change lanes, turn across a bicycle lane, slow down, back up, or drive down a long or steep hill

explanation: Check traffic behind you when you change lanes, turn across a bicycle lane, slow down, back up, or drive down a long or steep hill. Check more often when traffic is heavy.

question: Safe, respectful, and responsible driver behavior includes:

options.text: Only ensuring you wear a seatbelt
Ensuring all people use safety restraints, being fit to drive, showing empathy, respecting space, avoiding conflict, and taking care of the road environment

explanation: Responsible behavior includes: ensuring all people use safety restraints, being fit to drive, showing empathy toward others, respecting other road users' space, avoiding conflict regardless of fault, and taking care of the road environment.

question: Traffic advisories are:

options.text: Notifications about current or upcoming traffic conditions, incidents, or road closures

explanation: Traffic advisories are notifications or alerts about current or upcoming traffic conditions, incidents, or road closures. They help you make informed decisions about travel routes and avoid delays or hazards.

question: Traffic advisories are provided through:

options.text: Electronic road signs, social media, radio broadcasts, traffic websites, and mobile apps

explanation: Traffic advisories are provided in many ways including electronic road signs, social media, radio broadcasts, traffic websites, and mobile apps.

question: Litter on roads can cause accidents and create safety hazards for road users.
explanation: Litter creates safety hazards for people using roads and can cause accidents. Flammable or inflamed litter can spark wildfires, which is why fines for littering in Washington are severe.

question: You and your passengers are responsible for securing items you're transporting and properly throwing away trash.
explanation: You and your passengers are responsible for securing items you're transporting and properly throwing away trash. Washington State law sets minimum fines for littering and illegal dumping.

question: Leaving your car running while parked can release harmful gases like carbon monoxide, which can be lethal.
explanation: When you leave your car running while parked, especially in a garage, it can release harmful gases like carbon monoxide, which can be lethal. Idling also adds pollution to the air.

question: Small changes to help lower vehicle emissions include:

options.text: Leaving your engine running all the time
Turn off engine when parked, drive smoothly, keep tires inflated, and carpool or use public transport

explanation: To lower emissions: turn off engine if parked for a while, drive smoothly instead of speeding or braking hard, keep tires properly inflated for better gas mileage, and carpool or use public transport when possible.

question: Washington's Clean Car Law requires vehicles made in 2009 and later to meet strict clean air standards before they can be registered, licensed, or sold.
explanation: Washington's Clean Car Law requires vehicles made in 2009 and later to meet strict clean air standards before they can be registered, licensed, or sold.

question: Self-evaluation questions to ask during or after driving include:

options.text: Did anything surprise me? Did I surprise anyone? Was my driving legal, proficient, and smooth? What changes do I need to make?
How much gas did I use?

explanation: Self-evaluation questions include: Did anything surprise me? Did I surprise anyone? Was my driving legal, proficient, and smooth? What changes do I need to make for next time?

question: Regularly reviewing your driving skills helps you improve your abilities and maintain skills once they are developed.
explanation: Regularly reviewing your driving skills at the end of each drive helps you improve your abilities and maintain your skills once developed. Skills deteriorate over time, so regular evaluation keeps you driving at your best.

question: To keep your driving skills fresh, you should identify:

options.text: Only factors that contribute to changes in your skills
Factors that contribute to skill changes, changes in driving practices, changes in traffic laws, vehicle technology advancements, and lifelong learning opportunities

explanation: To keep skills fresh, identify: factors contributing to changes in driving skills, changes in driving practices, changes in traffic laws, changes and advancements in vehicle technology, and opportunities for lifelong learning related to driving.
